title-group.article-title: Study on the nonisothermal crystallization kinetics of ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymer of polypropylene

article-meta.aff: 1College of Materials and Energy, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China
2College of Materials Science and Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, China

author-notes.corresp: Zhang Hai-Yan, College of Materials and Energy, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, China Email: hyzhang@gdut.edu.cn

abstract.p: In order to discover how the grafted side chains affect the crystallization of the graft copolymers, the ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymers of polypropylene (PP; PPSM) were synthesized by solid-phase grafting of maleic anhydride, styrene and butyl acrylate onto PP. The Jeziorny and Mo methods were used to investigate the nonisothermal crystallization kinetics and polarizing microscope was used to study the crystalline morphology of PPSM. Results show that the grafted side chains not only promoted the heteronucleation of PP and reduced the size of spherulites but also hindered the growth of crystals resulting in the formation of imperfect crystallization region in PP. Due to the hindrance of the grafted side chains on the crystallization, the nonisothermal crystallization energy (ΔE) of PPSM calculated by the Kissinger equation is evidently higher than that of PP.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The modification of polypropylene (PP) by the grafting copolymerization is an important measure to improve the hydrophilicity of PP and extend its application scopes. The primary methods to prepare the graft copolymers are the melting graft copolymerization, 1 solvent graft copolymerization, 2 radiation graft copolymerization, 3 solid-phase graft copolymerization 4,5 and so forth. Compared with the other graft copolymerizations, the solid-phase graft copolymerization possesses the merits in terms of low grafting temperature, less side reaction, no solvent pollution and simple postdisposal. Canterino 6 first developed the method of solid-phase graft copolymerization in 1964. Then Borsig et al. 7 published a patent on the solid-phase graft copolymerization in 1980s. Lee et al. 8 –10 lucubrated the solid-phase graft copolymerization in 1990s. The traditionary solid-phase graft copolymerization is implemented by grafting individual monomer such as maleic anhydride (MAH) onto polymers. Recently, some researchers have developed the multimonomer solid-phase graft copolymers, 11
–16 which have higher graft degree than the individual monomer graft copolymer. Of these researchers, Jia and coworkers 14 –16 have developed the ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymer, which has the advantages of high graft degree, long graft chains and adjustable side chains and has shown outstanding interfacial compatibilization for the polyolefin composites and blends. 15,16

It is well known that the properties of PP depend significantly on its crystallization behaviors. The crystallization behavior of the PP graft copolymers was strongly affected by their structure, especially by the structure of the graft side chains. The crystallization behavior of the conventional single-monomer graft copolymers, such as PP-graft-MAH (PP-g-MAH), had been widely reported. 17 –19 Generally, the grafted side chains homopolymerized by MAH were short and tend to induce the heteronucleation of the graft copolymers. However, how these grafted side chains affect the crystallization of the graft copolymers when the grafted side chains were much longer than the conventional graft copolymers was less reported. In this article, we made an attempt to reveal the dual effects of grafted side chains on the crystallization of the ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymer of PP in terms of the crystallization behavior, crystallization kinetics and crystallization morphology. Differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) was used to investigate the crystallization behavior of the graft copolymer. The Jeziorny 20 and Mo methods 21 were used to describe the nonisothermal crystallization kinetics. The nonisothermal crystallization energy (ΔE) of the graft copolymer is calculated by the Kissinger equation. Polarized optical microscopy (POM) was used to characterize the crystallization morphology. The crystallization parameters of these crystallization processes were also determined.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: PP powder (melt flow rate = 0.22 g/10 min) used in the study was a commercial product supplied by Daqing Huake Co., Ltd (China) and used as received. MAH (AR grade) was ground before use. Styrene (St) and butyl acrylate (BA; AR grade) were extracted with a 0.1 mol/L NaOH solution to remove the inhibitors, then washed with distilled water and dried by molecular sieve before use. benzoyl peroxide (BPO; AR grade) was dissolved in methenyl chloride, precipitated with methanol and then dried in a vacuum desiccator after filtration.

sec.title: Synthesis of the PPSM
sec.p:
The synthesis of the ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymers of PP (PPSM) were carried out in a typical solid-state double-walled reactor 5 equipped with a condenser, an electric heater and a mechanical stirrer. The stirrer consists of a steel rod at one edge and a Teflon anchor perfectly fitting into the cylindrical shape of the reactor and, consequently, being able to remove scraps, whenever formed, from the reactor wall. The reactor was preheated to a given temperature and the stirring was started. The powdered PP and xylene were introduced into the reactor and then stirred under nitrogen environment for 10 min in order to swell the PP matrix. Then the monomers and the BPO were introduced into the reactor and allowed to react for 1 h. The grafted copolymers were taken out of the reactor after they were cooled down. 14 Before analysis, the samples were extracted to constant weight with acetone in a Soxhlet extractor at 80°C. The graft degree was calculated as follows 1
G D

M 1 is the weight of purified PPSM and M 0 the weight of pure PP. The graft degree of PPSM adopted in this article was 10%

sec.title: Analysis on the nonisothermal crystallization of the graft copolymer
sec.p: The nonisothermal crystallization behaviors of PPSM were operated on a DSC (TA DSC 2910) with sample weights of 5–10 mg. All operations were carried out under a nitrogen environment. Before the data gathering, the samples were heated to 220°C and held in the molten state for 5 min to eliminate the influence of thermal history. The sample melts were then subsequently quenched to room temperature at a rate of 5, 10, 15 and 20°C/min, respectively.

sec.title: Characterization of the crystallization morphology of the graft copolymer
sec.p: POM photographs were obtained using a German Zeiss microscope. The graft copolymer was crystallized by the nonisothermal mode. The samples were sandwiched between microscope cover slips, melted at 220°C for 5 min, and then cooled to room temperature at 20°C/min for completing crystallization.

sec.title: Methods for analyzing the nonisothermal crystallization kinetics
sec.p:
Many methods for describing the nonisothermal crystallization, such as the Jeziorny method, are based on the Avrami equation. 2
ln
− ln
1 −
X t
= n ln t + ln K

where X t is the relative crystallinity, n the Avrami exponent related to the type of nucleation and growth-process parameters and K the crystallization constant. Plotting ln[−ln(1 − X t)] versus lnt, a straight line can be obtained for the polymer system obeying the Avrami equation, and the parameters of n and K can be estimated from the plot. n and K are obtained from the slope and intercept of the line, respectively. However, the Avrami method indicates the relative crystallinity as a function of time. So, formula (2) has to change from time to temperature, as shown in the following equation 3
t =
(
T 0
− T
)
/
Φ

where t is the crystallization time, T 0 is the initial temperature of crystallization, T is the crystallization temperature and Φ is the cooling rate. Considering the effect of cooling rate, K is amended as follows 4
ln
K
c
=
ln K
Φ
K c is the Jeziorny crystallization constant and K is the Avrami crystallization constant.

Having assumed that nonisothermal crystallization process is the result of infinite small isothermal crystallization steps, Ozawa 22 modified the Avrami equation by incorporating a heating/cooling factor 5
X t
= 1 − exp ( − K ( T )
/
Φ m
)

where K(T) is the function of cooling rate and m is the Ozawa exponent depending on the dimension of crystal growth. However, the Ozawa equation had been shown not to adequately describe the nonisothermal crystallization kinetics of some polymers. 23 A new and interesting method proposed by Mo’s group is also used to describe the nonisothermal crystallization of polymers. For the nonisothermal crystallization process, physical variables concerning the process are relative to the degree of crystallization X t, cooling rate Φ and crystallization temperature T. By combining the Ozawa and Avrami equations, Mo’s group developed the following equations 6
ln Φ = ln F ( T ) − a ln t

where F(T) = [K(T )/Z t]1/
m and a = n/m, the ratio of the Avrami exponent n and Ozawa exponent m. F(T ) refer to the value of the cooling rate chosen at unit crystallization time, when the system has a defined relative crystallinity. A higher F(T ) means higher cooling rate was needed to approach defined relative crystallinity at unit crystallization time. Plotting lnΦ versus lnt, a straight line could be obtained. F(T ) and α could be estimated from the intercept and the slope of the line, respectively.

To estimate the activation energy of nonisothermal crystallization, the Kissinger equation 24 was commonly used 7
d
ln
Φ
/
T
p 2
d
1
/
T p
= −
Δ
E d
R

where R is the universal gas constant, T p is the crystallization peak temperature and ΔE is the activation energy for crystallization. Having plotted ln(Φ/T p
2 ) versus 1/T p, a straight line can be obtained. ΔE can be estimated from the slope of the lines.

sec.title: Nonisothermal crystallization behaviors of the graft copolymer
sec.p: The nonisothermal crystallization DSC curves are shown in Figure 1. The extension crystallization initial temperature (T a) and extension crystallization end temperature (T b) were used as the crystallization initial temperature and crystallization end temperature. The crystallization began from T a and ended at T b. T p is the crystallization peak temperature. Temperature at a–b was the crystallization zone. The crystallization parameters were listed in Table 1.

caption.p: The determination of the crystallization initial temperature and the crystallization end temperature (e.g. polypropylene, crystallization rate 10°C/min).
The parameters of T a and T b

fn.p: T a: initial temperature of crystallization; T b: end temperature of crystallization; PP: polypropylene; PPSM: ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymers of polypropylene.

sec.p: The result showed that the crystallization peak temperature of PP and PPSM shifted to lower temperature zone with increasing cooling rate. The reason was that the movement of the molecule segments lagged behind the change in temperature with increasing cooling rate.

The crystallization exotherms of pure PP and PPSM at the cooling rates of 5, 10, 15 and 20°C/min are shown in Figure 2. Some useful crystallization kinetic parameters can be read directly from the exotherm curves in terms of the Avrami exponent (n), temperature-dependent kinetic constant (K), half crystallization time (t 1/2) and the crystallization peak temperature (T p), as shown in Table 2. At a slower cooling rate, there is sufficient time to activate the nuclei; therefore, the crystallization can be growing at a higher temperature. On the contrary, at a faster cooling rate, the activation of nuclei occurs at a lower temperature. Consequently, crystallization nucleates at higher temperatures when the polymer samples were cooled at a slower scanning rate.

caption.p: Crystallization curves of PPSM at various cooling rates of (a) PP and (b) PPSM. 1: 5°C/min; 2: 10°C/min; 3: 15°C/min; 4: 20°C/min; PP: polypropylene; PPSM: ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymers of polypropylene.
The nonisothermal crystallization parameters of PP and PPSM

fn.p: PP: polypropylene; PPSM: ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymers of polypropylene; K c: Jeziorny crystallization constant; t 1/2: half crystallization time; T p: crystallization peak temperature; Avrami exponent related to the type of nucleation and growth-process parameters.

sec.p: In addition, the increasing cooling rate made the crystallization zone become wider. Although the lower temperature was favorable for arranging the molecule segments into the crystal lattice, the movement of the molecule segments was not intense enough to form the finished crystal. Therefore, the higher cooling rate resulted in the less complete crystal and wider crystallization temperature zone. At the same cooling rate, the crystallization peak temperature (T p) of PPSM was higher than that of PP, indicating that PPSM was easier to crystallize at high temperature than PP did. It meant that the heteronucleation of the grafted side chains conduced to improve the crystallization of the molecule segments of the graft copolymer.

Figure 3 shows the relative crystallinity X t as a function of temperature T for PP and PPSM at various cooling rates. Using equation (3), Figure 3 with the horizontal axis in the temperature scale could be converted into Figure 4, with the horizontal axis in time scale.

caption.p: The relative crystallinity of PPSM versus temperature for (a) PP and (b) PPSM. 1: 5°C/min; 2: 10°C/min; 3: 15°C/min; 4: 20°C/min; PP: polypropylene; PPSM: ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymers of polypropylene.

Plot of the relative crystallinity versus temperature for (a) PP and (b) PPSM. 1: 5°C/min; 2: 10°C/min; 3: 15°C/min; 4: 20°C/min; PP: polypropylene; PPSM: ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymers of polypropylene.

sec.p: It could be seen from Figure 4 that the faster cooling rate caused the time for completing the crystallization become shorter. The half crystallization time (t 1/2) of nonisothermal crystallization of PP and PPSM can be also obtained from Figure 4 and listed in Table 2. The results show that the half crystallization time (t 1/2) decreased with increasing cooling rate, since a higher cooling rate leads to a higher crystallization rate. At the same cooling rate, the half crystallization time of PPSM is lower than that of PP. This is attributed to the heteronucleation of the grafted side chains on the PP chains, which promoted the growth of crystal.

sec.title: Nonisothermal crystallization kinetics of the graft copolymer calculated by the Jeziorny method
sec.p: Using the Jeziorny method, straight plots of ln[−ln(1 − X t)] versus lnt were obtained and shown in Figure 5. The calculated nonisothermal crystallization parameters were listed in Table 2. It can be seen from Table 2 that the nonisothermal crystallization parameters of PPSM are similar to that of PP, indicating that the grafted side chains did not thoroughly change the crystallization mode of PP. The n value of the nonisothermal crystallization is within the range of 1–2, no matter for PP or PPSM, indicating that both PP and PPSM tended to nucleate in a one-dimensional mode. 25 At the same sample, n decreased and K increased with the increase in cooling rate. This means that the crystallization was easier to carry out at a higher cooling rate.

caption.p: Plot of ln[−ln(1 − X t)] versus lnt for (a) PP and (b) PPSM. 1: 5°C/min; 2: 10°C/min; 3: 15°C/min; 4: 20°C/min; PP: polypropylene; PPSM: ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymers of polypropylene.

sec.title: Nonisothermal crystallization kinetics of the graft copolymer calculated by the Mo method
sec.p: According to equation (6), the plots of lnΦ versus lnt for a given relative crystallinity were constructed and showed a straight line, as shown in Figure 6. F(T ) and a can be obtained from the intercept and the slope and listed in Table 3, respectively. F(T ) and a systematically increased with the increase in the relative crystallinity. F(T ) is the parameter that expressed the crystallization rate of the polymers. A higher F(T ) represents a lower crystallization rate needed to attain the given crystallinity. F(T ) ranges from 5.02 to 13.71 for PP and from 3.78 to 10.04 for PPSM. a ranges from 1.13 to 1.20 for PP and from 1.03 to 1.22 for PPSM. The F(T ) value of PPSM was lower than that of PP at the same relative crystallinity, suggesting that PPSM needed lower cooling rate than PP did to approach the same relative crystallinity because the heteronucleation of the grafted side chains accelerated the crystallization rate. We also reported the same results in the crystallization of PP-grafted MAH, methyl methacrylate(MMA) and BA. 26 In the graft copolymer of PP-g-MAH-MMA-BA, there was a decrease in F(T ) with increasing graft degree. A higher graft degree means more grafted side chains acted as heteronucleation agents to accelerate the crystallization rate and therefore decrease the F(T ).

caption.p: Plot of lnΦ versus lnt for (a) PP and (b) PPSM. 1: 20%; 2: 40%; 3: 60%; 4: 80%; PP: polypropylene; PPSM: ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymers of polypropylene.
The nonisothermal crystallization parameters of PP and PPSM calculated by the Mo method

fn.p: PP: polypropylene; PPSM: ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymers of polypropylene; X t: relative crystallinity; ΔE: nonisothermal crystallization energy.

sec.title: The activation energy of nonisothermal crystallization of the graft copolymer
sec.p:
Figure 7 shows the plot of
ln
Φ
Φ
T
p
2
T
p
2
versus 1/T p. The activation energy ΔE of nonisothermal crystallization can be estimated from the slope of the lines and are listed in Table 3. They were 154 and 209 KJ/mol for PP and PPSM, respectively. Obviously, the ΔE of nonisothermal crystallization of PPSM is higher than that of PP. This implied that PPSM needs more time to finish crystallization than PP did because the grafted side chains hindered the crystal growth of PPSM. Although the grafted side chains had heteronucleation on PP chains and promoted the nucleation rate of PP chains, their hindrance on the crystallization growth was predominant in the whole crystallization and caused the increase in the crystallization activation energy when the crystallization developed to certain phase.

caption.p:
The curves of
ln
Φ

T
p

T
p
2
versus 1/T p for PP and PPSM. PP: polypropylene; PPSM: ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymers of polypropylene.

sec.p: Figure 8 shows the POM images of PP and PPSM. The grafted side chains made the spherulite size reduce, suggesting that the grafted side chains also acted as heteronucleation agents. However, the crystal images in Figure 8 were irregular and incomplete due to the hindrance of the grafted side chains on the growth of the crystal.

caption.p: Polarizing microscope images of (a) PP and (b) PPSM. PP: polypropylene; PPSM: ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymers of polypropylene.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The nonisothermal crystallization behavior of ternary-monomer solid-phase graft copolymers of PP (PPSM) was investigated using DSC and POM. The grafted side chains not only promoted the heterogeneous nucleation of PPSM but also hindered the crystal growth of PPSM. The Jeziorny method and Mo method were successful in describing the nonisothermal crystallization kinetics. The analysis results by the Jeziorny method showed that the Avrami exponent n, ranging from 1 to 2, was not the integral number, indicating that the grafted side chains did not thoroughly change the nucleation mode. There were compound nucleation modes in the crystallization. The analysis by the Mo method showed that PPSM needed lower crystallization rate than PP did to attain the same crystallinity at unit crystallization time due to the heteronucleation of the grafted side chains. Meanwhile, the heteronucleation of the grafted side chains caused the decrease in the half crystallization time and the spherulite size of PPSM. The hindrance of the grafted side chains was shown by the increase in the nonisothermal crystallization activation energy and the incomplete crystallization images of PPSM.

fn.p: This work is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 20971027), by the Specialized Research Fund for the Doctoral Program of Higher Education of China (Grant No. 20094420110005 ), by the Guangdong Provincial Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No.9251009001000006), by the Science and Technology Program of Guangdong Province of China (Grant No. 2009A030301008, No.2009B090300017, No.2010A090200063, No.2010498E21, No.2010A011300041, No.2011B050300017, 2011A090200084).
